defs: a kind of plant.
a three-legged stool of low height; a tripod.
the vine Cissus pedata of Vitaceae family; iguana's foot vine.
a thick rope for tying elephants.
(pros.) a meter having three lines.
(pros.) a verse having four lines, three of which have three groups of three syllables(-uu) followed by one long syllable (-), and one line has four groups of three syllables (-uu).
the wild cotton plant Gossypium hirsutum (= G. neglectum).
its trifoliate leaves.
the plant Hemionites arifolia (= H. cordifolia) of Polypodiaceae family).

(astrol.) any of the six asterisms (Křttike, Punarvasu, Uttare, Viśakhe, Uttarāṣāḍa and Pūrvābhādre, which are considered inauspicious ones) whose three quarters are considered to be under one zodiac sign and the fourth under another sign.

a collection of scriptures originally recorded from oral traditions in the first century B.C., divided into one of three parts (Pitaka): sermons (Sutta Pitaka), the rules of the Buddhist order (Vinaya Pitaka), and several treatises on philosophy and psychology (Abhidhamma Pitaka); Pali canon; Tripitaka.
collectively three successive generations.
a gift of substantial worth which can be enjoyed by three successive generations.
the three strips marked horizontally on the forehead with sacred ashes, as a sectarian mark.
= ತ್ರಿಪುಂಡ್ರ.
(mus.) a singing or playing of the same note three times, mixing another note in between.
having the form of a triangle; three-cornered; triangular.
a slender, straight, pointed missile that is shot from a bow; an arrow.
the shore or bank of a body of water.
the length from the elbow to the tip of the middle-finger when stretched straight, which was considered a unit of length; a cubit.
the brittle-pods containing upto three edible seeds, of the plant Arachis hypogaea of Papilionaceae family; the pea-nut.
a group of three things, subjects, persons that are mutually related.
a measure of time in music, having one beat followed varying number of counts (as three, four, five, seven etc.), two units having one beat and one count each.
the central point between two eye brows, just above the nose.
the knowledge of the phenomenal world, soul and Śiva.

the plant Convolvulus turpethum of Convolvulaceae family.
the plant Ipomea turpethum of Convolvulaceae family.
2.a particular kind of gait in dancing.
(pros.) a metre having three rhyming lines.
a variety of flute.
(pros.) a kind of alliteration in which three consonants, between the first and the fourth vowels, repeats in each lines of a verse.
a set of three fruits, gooseberry (Phyllanthus emblica), myrobalan (Terminalia chebulan) and Belleric myrobalan (Terminalia bellirica), used for medicinal purpose.

= ತ್ರಿಫಲ.
(dance) a standing with neck, waist and the leg (at knee) bent slightly.

collectively the narcotic, hallucinogen drugs that are smoked, drunk or eaten (or chewed).

that which is bent at three points or has three hook-like points.

a mode or way of bending one's body at three points (at the neck, waist and knee).

(musc.) a type of regulated vibration of a note around its natural place while singing or playing on musical instruments.
(geom.) a closed plane figure having three sides and three angles; a triangle.
the three worlds, the physical world, lower region and the heaven.
(collectively) the three subdivisions in Brāhmaṇa community, based on the philosophical teachings of Śankara, Rāmānuja and Mādhva, popularly known as Smārtha, Srī Vaiṣṇava and Vaiṣṇava respectively.
belonging to the three subdivisions in Brāhmaṇa community, based on the philosophical teachings of Śankara, Rāmānuja and Mādhva, popularly known as Smārtha, Srī Vaiṣṇava and Vaiṣṇava respectively.

(only in pl.) a man belonging to the three subdivisions in Brāhmaṇa community, based on the philosophical teachings of Śankara, Rāmānuja and Mādhva, popularly known as Smārtha, Srī Vaiṣṇava and Vaiṣṇava.
arrogance caused by one's education (or knowledge), wealth and nobility of birth or status.
(phil.) the three objects that make a spiritual aspirant dirty - women, wealth and property.
(pros.) a syllable having the length of three prosodic units.

(pros.) a syllabic feet with three short or one long with one long units.
(collectively) three divisions of something (as arithmetic, geometry and algebra of mathematics).

having three letters or syllables (as a word or metric foot); formed by the combination of three syllables.

the division of a 24-hour-day, which is further divided into three subdivisions of three hours each; evening.

a linear measure that is three times the length of the arm from the end of the closed fist to the elbow.
the three worlds, the physical world, lower region and the heaven.

(dial.) a ceremony observed on the fourth day of initiation of a Brāhmaṇa boy into religious learning.
a club, heavy staff used as a weapon.
a churning stick.
a stick used to strike a percussion instrument.
the crossbar of a balance.
the wooden blade used to row a boat; an oar.
a length of four cubit.
a staff of the tree Butea frondosa held by a Brāhmaṇa boy while being initiated into religious learning.
a rod or staff, usu. ornamented, held as a symbol of authority; a sceptre.
the stalk of a plant.
a long, slender piece of wood (as the one used to uphold a banner).
a particular type of array in which soldiers are placed one behind the other in a row.
the coarse, unrefined sugar; jaggery.
the male organ through which semen and urine are ejected; the penis.
punishment - a) a punishing or being punished; b) a penalty imposed on an offender for a crime or wrongdoing.
an attack, assault, punishment of a wrong doer, enemy, etc., as one of the four expedients used in achieving a goal in politics.
an army of soldiers.
the quality or fact of being useless; uselessness.
a wrong deed.

a type of physical exercise in which, standing on the toes and the palms, the body is lowered (without allowing the knees to touch the ground), and slightly pushed forward bending the back upward; ದಂಡ ಕೊಡು daṇḍa koḍu to pay a sum of money as a punishment for having done an offence; ದಂಡ ಹಾಕು daṇḍa hāku to impose a sum of money as a punishment for an offence; ದಂಡಂ ದಶಗುಣಂ ಭವೇತ್ daṇḍam daśam guṇam bhavēt (loosely) a maxim to denote that, when other ways fail, one can be tamed, taught by chastising; baculine argument.
to be punished; to be imposed a sum of money as a punishment.
to impose a sum of money as a punishment for an offence.
= ದಂಡತೆರು.
a thin, long staff (as of a bamboo).
the forest between the Narmada and Gōdāvari rivers in the northern part of southern of India.
(pros.) a meter, having more than twenty six syllables in each quarter.
a usual method or custom; a convention; a practice.
a magnet in the form of a magnet; a bar-magnet.
a staff carried by a brāhmaṇa boy initiated into religious learning or an ascetic.
a thick, short staff.
= ದಂಡನೆ.
to pay a sum of money as a punishment for having done an offence.
(fig.) to pay unnecessarily.
= ದಂಡಾಯ.
= ದಂಡದೋಷ.
a sum of money imposed as punishment for an offence.
= ದಂಡಾಯ.
a man who walks with the help of a stick.
Yama, the Hindu god of Death and who awards punishment to human beings after their death.
a holder of a sceptre as a symbol of sovereignty.
a man holding a staff, as a guard, doorkeeper, etc.
an officer in the court of law who implements the punishment awarded by the judge.

the act or holding a staff (as by a guard).
